newsitem.title: PERU: Peru government and rebels start talks- Red Cross.
newsitem.headline: Peru government and rebels start talks- Red Cross.

text.p: Peru's government and Marxist rebels holding VIP hostages at the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima on Friday started a second round of face-to-face talks to end the crisis, the Red Cross said.

Government negotiator Domingo Palermo arrived first at a Red Cross safe house used for a first round of talks last Tuesday. Minutes later, a Red Cross car entered the diplomatic compound and, out of sight of witnesses, picked up a rebel and took him across the street to the safe house, Red Cross spokeswoman Cecile Baux said.
As the Red Cross car pulled out of the compound, Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) rebel hymns were heard coming from inside the residence, witnessses said.
The rebel inside the car was believed to be Rolly Rojas, the MRTA's second-in-command, who attended Tuesday's talks.
Also present at the meeting were members of a guarantors' commission, made up of officials of the Red Cross, the Vatican and the Canadian government, as well as a Japanese government observer.

Tuesday's meeting produced a pledge for further talks but little more apparent progress towards a peaceful solution. The rebels refuse to give up their demand for the release of over 400 jailed comrades, which the government flatly rejects.
